newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK folk rush to buy 97 souvenir British banknotes.
newsitem.headline: HK folk rush to buy 97 souvenir British banknotes.

text.p: Hundreds of Hong Kong people on Friday rushed to snap up the latest in a gush of souvenirs of the British colony's looming handover to China -- special Bank of England five-pound notes with a commemorative 1997 cipher.
And in the best tradition of this money-spinning territory, it wasn't the memory that was so important but the prospect of the banknotes making huge gains in value.

"The value has the potential to go up, it's a beautiful design, it's a limited edition, so I think it's a very good buy, said housewife Elaine Fong, as she scrambled to pick up one of the bills, on sale at a financial services fair.
"We are very pleased to see so many people. I thought there would be a good response," Robin Baker, commercial operations manager of the Bank of England, told Reuters.
Long queues snaked in and out of the Hong Kong Convention Centre, with crowds avoiding other stalls and the main purpose of the fair -- to view and deal in the currencies of the world.
Word had got around that the venerable old central bank had reconfigured its presses to print 500,000 five pounds notes numbered with "HK97" serials.
Single notes cost HK$138 to HK$150 (US$17.85 to US$19.40), while an uncut sheet with 35 of the notes cost HK$5,000.
Those with unusual numbers were auctioned off. A note with the serial number "HK97 979797" fetched HK$68,000.

Britain is handing its colony of 156 years back to China at midnight this June 30, and the territory has seen a flurry of souvenir items hit the streets, ranging from t-shirts and pens to stamps, coins and watches commemorating the flag change.
